### Transforms (Lambda Layer)

<details open>

<summary>September update</summary>

I'm no longer using Lamda layers to handle sharp. Currently I just run a script to copy it from my root `node_modules/` into the bundle. This is primarily a workaround to the fact that I've not figured out how to just run `npm install --arch=x64 --platform=linux --libc=glibc --prefix='.open-next/server-functions/default' sharp` in my monorepo, without getting caught up in a registry timeout / 404 error for the local packages that don't exist in the `npm` registry. Likewise, `bun` doesn't support `npm`'s `--prefix` flag.

So, I decided to just write a brute force script that copies `sharp` and it's dependencies into the output bundle from `open-next`, specifically into the default server function. A smarter script would grab the named deps that would result from a call to `npm i sharp`, then figure out which ones to install then copy over. However, Sharp seem's pretty stable, I was tired, and I just wanted something that worked immediately and I hard-coded the paths. So, have a gander at my silly little script.

```ts
/*
 * The bun shebang probably isn't necessary (no Bun specific APIs).
 * But, it ensures I get Bun's versions of the Node filesystem APIs.
 */
#! /usr/bin/env bun

import { cp, mkdir } from 'node:fs/promises';
import { join } from 'node:path';

const cwd = process.cwd();
const monoRepoCorrection = '../../';
const node_modules = join(cwd, monoRepoCorrection, './node_modules');
const openNextServerDefault = join(cwd, '.open-next/server-functions/default');

const sharpInstall = `sharp`;

const sharpDeps = ['color', 'detect-libc', 'semver'];
const colorDeps = ['color-convert', 'color-string'];
const colorStringDeps = ['color-name', 'simple-swizzle'];
// color-convert depends on color-name

const pkgsToCopy = [sharpInstall, ...sharpDeps, ...colorDeps, ...colorStringDeps];

const t0 = performance.now();

export default async function copySharp() {
  try {
    console.info('copying', sharpInstall, 'to:', openNextServerDefault);
    const pkgPaths = pkgsToCopy.map((pkg) => {
      const from = `${node_modules}/${pkg}`;
      const to = `${openNextServerDefault}/node_modules/${pkg}`;
      return {
        source: from,
        dest: to,
      };
    });
    for await (const pkg of pkgPaths) {
      console.info('creating dirs from', pkg.source, 'to:', pkg.dest);
      await mkdir(pkg.dest, { recursive: true });
    }
    for await (const copied of pkgPaths) {
      console.info('copying', copied.source, 'to:', copied.dest);
      await cp(copied.source, copied.dest, { recursive: true });
    }

    console.info('finished in ', performance.now() - t0, `ms`);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error(err);
  }
}

await copySharp();
```

I've set it up in my `turbo.json` so it runs immediately after `SHARP_VERSION=0.33.5 bunx open-next build`.

```json
{
  "extends": ["//"],
  "tasks": {
    "build:open-next": {
      "env": ["OPEN_NEXT_VERSION", "NEXT_PUBLIC_DEPLOYED_URL"],
      "outputs": [
        ".open-next/**",
        "!.open-next/cache/**",
        "public/dist/**",
        "public/sw.js",
        ".contentlayer",
        ".contentlayermini"
      ],
      "inputs": ["$TURBO_DEFAULT$", ".env", ".env.local", ".env.development", ".env.production"]
    },
    "copy-sharp": {
      "inputs": ["$TURBO_DEFAULT$", ".env", ".env.local", ".env.development", ".env.production", ".open-next/**"],
      "outputs": [".open-next/server-functions/default/**"],
      "dependsOn": ["build:open-next"]
    }
  }
}
```

</details>

### Nix Compatibility

<details open>

<summary>September update</summary>

This is still technically an issue, but I've since realized you can just run `sst` from the package manager, i.e., `bun run sst $COMMAND`. However, since I already went through the effort, I've continued to just run it from a distrobox container.

</details>

Iâll admit, Iâm a fairly niche user, but Nix compatibility would be hella cool. While thereâs actually [an open PR in the nixpkgs repo](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/pull/300478) to add `sst` to nixpkgs, due to the nature of the `sst` CLI, compatibility with Nix is a little clunky. However, thereâs [an open issue in the Ion repo](https://github.com/sst/ion/issues/143) discussing a possible solution that could be implemented on SSTâs end to make it _just work_ with Nix, so perhaps `sst` will be fully compatible with Nix one day.

In any event, your best bet when working with SST applications on NixOS for now, is likely going to be to run the `sst` CLI from a distrobox container. However, you could probably get the binaries working via `steam-run` if Iâm honest, but I havenât tried it yet.

## Working with Three.js, & React Three Fiber

[Three.js](https://threejs.org/) is a WebGL wrapper written in JavaScript, and [React Three Fiber](https://docs.pmnd.rs/react-three-fiber/getting-started/introduction) is a React renderer for three.js. Also, it is absolutely the coolest thing Iâve ever managed to learn in all my years spent developing for the web.

Initially, I was going to try to create most of this site in it. This would mean the majority of elements youâd interact with, would be contained entirely in the three.js canvas! Sorta like how [Google renders Google Docs](https://workspaceupdates.googleblog.com/2021/05/Google-Docs-Canvas-Based-Rendering-Update.html). The only thing that stopped me, was when I realized what this would mean in reality: long load times, no server components, no SSR.

Now, for Google Docs or anything that falls firmly in the _software_ category, those supposed _drawbacks_, are just the baseline expectation. No one expects something so heavy to load instantly. However, for something much closer to a traditional website, like a blog? _Oh, those are drawbacks._

As such, I made the tough decision to be much more selective about where and how I use the Three.js canvas. The landing page I felt was an important place to demonstrate my knowledge of both it & GLSL shaders, so thatâs what I put there. However, because it is the landing page, I did my best to create as simple a scene as possible; shaving bandwidth down as much as I could. Because originally I was going to do [something much heavier](/projects/bot-clicker), but shifted gears once Iâd realized _how heavy_.

However, because this site renders its content much more traditionally, I was able to make heavy use of server components, experimenting with their weirdness to my hearts content.

Aside, itâs important to state itâs possible to mix vanilla Three.js with React Three Fiber. Of course, doing so defeats the purpose of the latter a tad bit, but occasionally Iâve found it useful to use a [primitive object](https://docs.pmnd.rs/react-three-fiber/api/objects#putting-already-existing-objects-into-the-scene-graph) every now and then.

### Integrating with Next.js

When I first began this project, I took some inspiration from the [pmndrs/react-three-next](https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-next) boilerplate, even basing my `next.config.mjs` off it. Itâs actually how I discovered you can chain plugins with an accumulator function.

The most interesting thing about the boilerplate is it uses [pmndrs/tunnel-rat](https://github.com/pmndrs/tunnel-rat) to create an alternative [`<View />`](https://github.com/pmndrs/drei?tab=readme-ov-file#view) component from [pmndrs/drei](https://github.com/pmndrs/drei). In testing, I couldnât really figure out a benefit for doing this. My hunch is that the tunnel-rat method predates some changes to the `<View />` component which mightâve complicated things in Next.js.

Regardless, the `<View />` component from either method works with the Next.js App router just fine. The main benefit of cutting up the canvas like this, is that you donât need to wait for it to load in again between pages, granted youâve wrapped those pages with a component that provides a canvas. The only slowdowns youâd see, would result from loading models. Ideally, those models should be lazy loaded/dynamically imported with [next/dynamic](https://nextjs.org/docs/pages/building-your-application/optimizing/lazy-loading).

As well, if youâre working with WebGL in a Next.js application, youâre going to want to put `use client` at the top of the pages/components that make use of it. WebGL relies heavily on a clientâs hardware, especially WebGPU. While you can SSR pages that import client components featuring these elements, Next.js/React wonât compile if you try to use these APIs directly in a server component for obvious reasons.

### Paper Cuts with Safari

Originally, I was going to make heavy use of the `<View />` component. The **only** thing that stopped me from doing so, was when I realized how _ungraceful_ it looked in Safari. You see, if the `<View />` doesnât take up the entire page, the `<View />` component starts to jitter as you scroll up or down. Here's an [open issue](https://github.com/pmndrs/drei/issues/1890) demonstrating this behavior.

According to this [comment](https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-next/issues/124#issuecomment-1508105739), this behavior occurs because Safari doesnât sync scroll events with the [`window.requestAnimationFrame()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/requestAnimationFrame) API. This would help to explain why only Safari seems to experience this issue.

One solution to this is to use a virtual-scroller like [Lenis](https://lenis.darkroom.engineering/). It's just that, I've got some reservations about that solution.

While, I think virtual-scrollers like Lenis look and feel great on desktop browsers, especially with a mouse scroll wheel, touch based Safari interactions with Lenis are another story. While I can't comment on how something like Lenis _feels_ on a touch-based Android device running Chrome (Chromium) or Firefox (Gecko), I can talk about how I'm not enthusiastic about it on Safari (WebKit) for iOS.

Due to the nature of Safari, there are some [limitations](https://github.com/darkroomengineering/lenis?tab=readme-ov-file#limitations) to using Lenis as a solution. While yes, it does fix the jitters, the fact that fps is suddenly capped to 60, and then an abysmal 30 fps if power saving mode is engaged, doesn't thrill me.

Sure, a virtual-scroller is better than jitters, I won't argue that fact. However, on mobile Safari at least, virtual-scrollers result in a scrolling experience that I honestly find irritating. When I tested Lenis, I found I couldn't _flick_ up or down a page readily without it stopping in its tracks, nor could I scroll in either direction at a consistent speed. You can even replicate this behavior on the [Lenis](https://lenis.darkroom.engineering/) website itself.

My eventual solution, was to just do away with the `<View />` component, and embed the canvas directly. I did this after investigating [Sketchfab](https://sketchfab.com/3d-models/popular)'s website, where I realized they solved the _jitter_ problem by not using `<View />` components at all, as they simply embed the canvas into whatever model-preview you're currently hovering over.

Although, that solution is quite traditional, it worked for my purposes however, so that's what I went with. Nevertheless, If you are creating a complete Three.js _experience_, then I'd suggest using Lenis. I say this despite my reservations, because Lenis or another virtual-scroller are really your only options.

## My Favorite React State-Management Solution: Zustand

![zustandâs mascot, an adorable bear](../../../assets/images/non-oc/bear.jpg)

Created by the [Poimandres dev collective](https://pmnd.rs/) (Pmndrs)âthe same collective behind React Three Fiber & the React Three ecosystemâ[Zustand](https://zustand-demo.pmnd.rs/) is a featherweight alternative to [React Redux](https://react-redux.js.org/), and I love the little state-management solution dearly.

<aside>

How could you not!? Itâs got a cute bear as a mascot!

</aside>

Itâs incredibly minimal (feeling more like an extension of Reactâs Context API), which makes learning it, and integrating it rather painless.

In addition, because it comes from Poimandres, it integrates superbly into a `react-three/fiber` scene, with minimal performance impact. You can see it in action on their demo site, or you can see how I used it for my _toy_-clicker game, [bot-clicker](/projects/bot-clicker), on its project page.

However, integrating Zustand with React Three isnât the only way to use it, of course. The theme toggle in the navbar actually relies on it. While Iâm persisting the theme state via the localStorage API, rather than with Zustandâs [Persist middleware](https://docs.pmnd.rs/zustand/integrations/persisting-store-data), itâs kept in memory via a zustand store.

To pass this state around, a provider component wraps the navbar & theme toggle, as well as any other component that needs this context. In effect, state can be sent from the sliding switch, to any of the wrapped components.

While, the primary function of the sliding switch adds or removes the _dark_ class on the root HTML elementâthis is [used by tailwind CSS](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/dark-mode) to change colors from light to dark and vice-versaâitâs utility in being used in a Zustand store allows me to modify non-css elements too, like a Three.js scene to reflect the updated theme state.

Overall, Iâm thrilled by the existence of Zustand, especially having gotten used to the ease of [Svelteâs store API](https://svelte.dev/docs/svelte-store), that makes state management a _breeze_. So, it was really nice to have found this minimalist, but really powerful, alternative for React as well.

## Discussion

### Overall Thoughts on Next.js

Next.js 14 is the current major version of Next.js, having released close to a year ago (<time dateTime='2023-10-26T02:00:00.000Z'>10/26/23</time>), with the latest minor update (non-canary) just this past week (14.2.5). Now, having last used Next.js when it was at version 11?, developing with Next 14 has admittedly been quite the learning experience. Even so, Iâm overall quite satisfied with how everything turned out.

Granted, the most common complaint youâll find about Next.js is usually in reference to the cognitive load it puts on developersâa result of its breadth of features, customizability, and the level of control you have over its various APIs (caching, routing, rendering, etc.)âand I donât disagree with that assessment. Next.js has a lot of moving parts, ergo itâs a lot to learn. Additionally, it really didnât help that googling the various Next.js APIs and clicking on what pops up will typically take you to the old Pages router version instead of the newer App router alternative/equivalent API. The latter is a little better nowadays, but still not perfect (guess Vercelâs SEO game was just too good).

Furthermore, Iâll even admit to knowing that I donât know everything about Next.js. For example, Iâve got a rough idea of its caching model, but itâs not as complete as Iâd like. However, this isnât because I think the caching model is overcomplicated, itâs more so just been a lack of need to dive so deeply into it (_perhaps exploring it in-depth would make a good blog post?_).

Ignorance aside, once I managed to get a good enough mental-model of Next.js in my head, working with it was pretty smooth. At this point, I find most of the added thinking is spent in the optimization and testing departments.

In sum, itâs my opinion that Nextâs key strengths more than make up for its drawbacks. What I like the most about Next.js is just how, well, _next_ it is. It integrates unreleased features from React (which, albeit annoying sometimes for compatibility, but I understand why), itâs also incredibly forward-thinking in the features it provides, like _streaming_. Not to mention the level of control you have over even minute details like the precise runtime for a page route. Additionally, itâs one of the most _batteries-included_ frameworks Iâve used as far as JavaScript/TypeScript frameworks go, and thatâs a huge plus too. Oh, and it makes TypeScript a first-class citizen to top it all off, which makes my brain happy.

### Overall Thoughts on Ion/SST

Ion might still be in beta, but once I was able to get things going, it's been a really solid deployment tool. Ionâs major defining difference from its predecessors, and leading reason why I chose beta software over the stable SST v2, is that it uses Pulumi and Terraform providers to provision your IaC, instead of Amazonâs CDK/CFN. The fact that your appâs architecture can be made up from services provided by a whole host of different cloud service providers instead of just the services offered by AWS, was a major selling point to me.

The only real drawback to Ion/SST that I can think of, is youâll [need to set up your own CI/CD pipeline](https://docs.sst.dev/going-to-production#deploy-from-git) with something like [GitHub Actions](https://github.com/features/actions) or [Circle CI](https://circleci.com/). Well, unless of course you want to run `sst deploy` manually after every commit, then don't let me stop you. If configuring that sounds like a drag, SST conveniently provides a CI/CD service called [seed](https://seed.run/), which should _just work_ with an Ion/SST codebase OOTB.

Overall, Iâm incredibly pleased with using SST/Ion to deploy Next.js applications to AWS (CloudFront, Lambda, S3, etc.). Even though Ion isnât quite stable yet (itâll be renamed SST v3 by then), Iâm still quite satisfied with it. While it canât replace all the tools in my DevOps toolbox (nor should it), itâs definitely going to get some heavy usage.

### Conclusion

This site is a Next.js 14 application, and with the help of Ion/SST + OpenNext, it gets deployed via serverless AWS Lambda functions, with integrated S3 buckets (& other AWS Services), where itâs then distributed onto CloudFrontâs CDN for your enjoyment.

While both Next.js and Ion/SST have their flaws, theyâre both fantastic tools in my full stack toolbox. Their strengths more than make up for their perceived weaknesses, and I'll happily use this combination again going forward.

In addition, there's a whole slew of neat tools and technologies contained in this sites stack that I really enjoyed learning and building with. It's quite likely I'll find a use for these tools and libraries in later projects as well.

Overall, I couldn't be happier with how this site came out, and I'm excited to see how both it and I, will evolve over time.

Finally, if you have any questions, or want to share your thoughts on this piece, or would like to submit corrections, please either reach out to me on social media, leave a comment below, open an [issue](https://github.com/laniakita/website/issues/new/choose), or submit a PR to the [repo](https://github.com/laniakita/website) directly. Whichever way, Iâd love to hear your thoughts, and I appreciate (constructive) feedback, thank you.

`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["A while ago I\u2019d found ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://martincapodici.com/2023/06/08/nextjs-undocumented-features/",children:"this post"})," by ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://martincapodici.com/",children:"Martin Capodici"})," on their blog that describes how they had uncovered an undocumented debug flag used to print out helpful diagnostics for the router cache in Next.js. All you need to do is set is ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"NEXT_PRIVATE_DEBUG_CACHE=1"}),", and the caching diagnostics are yours."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Like I said, it\u2019s not the coolest secret flag in the world, but I did find something cool when I was reading up on it. Interestingly, I stumbled upon a rad little package called ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://caching-tools.github.io/next-shared-cache/",children:(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"@neshca/cache-handler"})})," that just so happens to describe the behavior of ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"NEXT_PRIVATE_DEBUG_CACHE"})," in a little more detail via their ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://caching-tools.github.io/next-shared-cache/troubleshooting",children:"troubleshooting guide"}),"."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Granted, I don\u2019t have a need for such a utility, but if you\u2019re hosting a Next.js application on a distributed system like a k8s cluster, this might be the package for you. ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"@neshca/cache-handler"})," solves the cache validation issues borne from multiple instances of the same Next.js application, by letting you replace the default Next.js cache with a shared cache via special ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://caching-tools.github.io/next-shared-cache/redis",children:"cache handlers"}),". `,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"Fun caching tools aside, extra debugging information is always handy. So, it\u2019s nice that Next.js has these flags built-in, even if they\u2019re frustratingly lacking in documentation."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.h2,{id:"what-i-like-about-sstion",children:"What I Like about SST/Ion"}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["The Ion flavor of SST is ",(0,e.jsx)(n.strong,{children:(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"rad"})}),". I am enamored with its endless utility, Ion may as well be a Swiss Army Knife in my DevOps toolbox. In integrating the Pulumi engine into Ion, there\u2019s a wide range of Pulumi (& even Terraform) providers available OOTB in the form of components, letting you configure an application\u2019s Infrastructure as Code (IaC) with ease."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Likewise, Ion provides a CLI in the form of ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"sst"}),", which does much more than just deploy your infra. Depending on your ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"sst.config.ts"}),", the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"sst"})," CLI provides a wrapper around your application\u2019s ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"dev"})," and ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"build"})," scripts to inject resources defined and linked in your IaC, right into your application. This occurs in both your local dev environment and of course on your production infra upon ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"sst deploy"}),"; it\u2019s quite wonderful."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.h3,{id:"iac-is-rad",children:"IaC is Rad"}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"I\u2019m a huge nerd, I get that, but something about declaring infra from a source controlled config file, and spinning it up from the command line just makes my brain happy. It probably scratches the same itch that Nix/NixOS does."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"If I had to reason why I\u2019m so delighted by IaC, I imagine the reproducibility aspect is likely the largest contributing factor. There\u2019s something inherently comforting about the fact that I can just copy my IaC files over to a new project (with fresh API keys). Equally, it\u2019s nice I could even roll back my infra in the same project (based on the config from a previous commit), instantly creating the same backend infra as before."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"While of course infra requirements differ between projects, it\u2019s really nice to have a base configuration that I can use as a boilerplate in my other projects. If only because it saves me the step of rewriting many of the same infra declarations."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"Likewise, the fact I can save even more time by skipping (imperative) setup hell\u2014endlessly clicking through menus, double-checking everything looks good, then getting reset because I accidentally skipped a required field\u2014is a literal godsend for me. So, the time savings factor (a direct benefit of IaC) gets a huge plus from me too."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.h3,{id:"pulumi--its-terraform-bridge",children:"Pulumi (& it\u2019s Terraform Bridge)"}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["The Ion flavor of SST uses Pulumi providers (& by extension Terraform providers) as components, that allow you to define your applications IaC. `,(0,e.jsx)(n.h3,{id:"linked-resources",children:"Linked Resources"}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["It\u2019s important to reiterate that Ion isn\u2019t simply a different flavor of Terraform, as SST themselves ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://sst.dev/blog/moving-away-from-cdk.html#what-ion-is-not",children:"pointed out in that same blog post"}),". `,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["All you need to do is link your defined resources back to your application in its ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"sst.config.ts"})," file. `,(0,e.jsx)(n.h2,{id:"working-with-threejs--react-three-fiber",children:"Working with Three.js, & React Three Fiber"}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:[(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://threejs.org/",children:"Three.js"})," is a WebGL wrapper written in JavaScript, and ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://docs.pmnd.rs/react-three-fiber/getting-started/introduction",children:"React Three Fiber"})," is a React renderer for three.js. `,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Initially, I was going to try to create most of this site in it. The only thing that stopped me, was when I realized what this would mean in reality: long load times, no server components, no SSR."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Now, for Google Docs or anything that falls firmly in the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"software"})," category, those supposed ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"drawbacks"}),", are just the baseline expectation. No one expects something so heavy to load instantly. However, for something much closer to a traditional website, like a blog? ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"Oh, those are drawbacks."})]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["As such, I made the tough decision to be much more selective about where and how I use the Three.js canvas. The landing page I felt was an important place to demonstrate my knowledge of both it & GLSL shaders, so that\u2019s what I put there. However, because it is the landing page, I did my best to create as simple a scene as possible; shaving bandwidth down as much as I could. Because originally I was going to do ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"/projects/bot-clicker",children:"something much heavier"}),", but shifted gears once I\u2019d realized ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"how heavy"}),"."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"However, because this site renders its content much more traditionally, I was able to make heavy use of server components, experimenting with their weirdness to my hearts content."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Aside, it\u2019s important to state it\u2019s possible to mix vanilla Three.js with React Three Fiber. Of course, doing so defeats the purpose of the latter a tad bit, but occasionally I\u2019ve found it useful to use a ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://docs.pmnd.rs/react-three-fiber/api/objects#putting-already-existing-objects-into-the-scene-graph",children:"primitive object"})," every now and then."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.h3,{id:"integrating-with-nextjs",children:"Integrating with Next.js"}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["When I first began this project, I took some inspiration from the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-next",children:"pmndrs/react-three-next"})," boilerplate, even basing my ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"next.config.mjs"})," off it. It\u2019s actually how I discovered you can chain plugins with an accumulator function."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["The most interesting thing about the boilerplate is it uses ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://github.com/pmndrs/tunnel-rat",children:"pmndrs/tunnel-rat"})," to create an alternative ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://github.com/pmndrs/drei?tab=readme-ov-file#view",children:(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"<View />"})})," component from ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://github.com/pmndrs/drei",children:"pmndrs/drei"}),". In testing, I couldn\u2019t really figure out a benefit for doing this. My hunch is that the tunnel-rat method predates some changes to the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"<View />"})," component which might\u2019ve complicated things in Next.js."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Regardless, the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"<View />"})," component from either method works with the Next.js App router just fine. The main benefit of cutting up the canvas like this, is that you don\u2019t need to wait for it to load in again between pages, granted you\u2019ve wrapped those pages with a component that provides a canvas. The only slowdowns you\u2019d see, would result from loading models. Ideally, those models should be lazy loaded/dynamically imported with ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://nextjs.org/docs/pages/building-your-application/optimizing/lazy-loading",children:"next/dynamic"}),"."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["As well, if you\u2019re working with WebGL in a Next.js application, you\u2019re going to want to put ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"use client"})," at the top of the pages/components that make use of it. WebGL relies heavily on a client\u2019s hardware, especially WebGPU. While you can SSR pages that import client components featuring these elements, Next.js/React won\u2019t compile if you try to use these APIs directly in a server component for obvious reasons."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.h3,{id:"paper-cuts-with-safari",children:"Paper Cuts with Safari"}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Originally, I was going to make heavy use of the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"<View />"})," component. The ",(0,e.jsx)(n.strong,{children:"only"})," thing that stopped me from doing so, was when I realized how ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"ungraceful"})," it looked in Safari. You see, if the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"<View />"})," doesn\u2019t take up the entire page, the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"<View />"})," component starts to jitter as you scroll up or down. Here's an ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://github.com/pmndrs/drei/issues/1890",children:"open issue"})," demonstrating this behavior."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["According to this ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-next/issues/124#issuecomment-1508105739",children:"comment"}),", this behavior occurs because Safari doesn\u2019t sync scroll events with the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/requestAnimationFrame",children:(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"window.requestAnimationFrame()"})})," API. This would help to explain why only Safari seems to experience this issue."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["One solution to this is to use a virtual-scroller like ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://lenis.darkroom.engineering/",children:"Lenis"}),". It's just that, I've got some reservations about that solution."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["While, I think virtual-scrollers like Lenis look and feel great on desktop browsers, especially with a mouse scroll wheel, touch based Safari interactions with Lenis are another story. While I can't comment on how something like Lenis ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"feels"})," on a touch-based Android device running Chrome (Chromium) or Firefox (Gecko), I can talk about how I'm not enthusiastic about it on Safari (WebKit) for iOS."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Due to the nature of Safari, there are some ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://github.com/darkroomengineering/lenis?tab=readme-ov-file#limitations",children:"limitations"})," to using Lenis as a solution. While yes, it does fix the jitters, the fact that fps is suddenly capped to 60, and then an abysmal 30 fps if power saving mode is engaged, doesn't thrill me."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Sure, a virtual-scroller is better than jitters, I won't argue that fact. However, on mobile Safari at least, virtual-scrollers result in a scrolling experience that I honestly find irritating. When I tested Lenis, I found I couldn't ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"flick"})," up or down a page readily without it stopping in its tracks, nor could I scroll in either direction at a consistent speed. You can even replicate this behavior on the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://lenis.darkroom.engineering/",children:"Lenis"})," website itself."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["My eventual solution, was to just do away with the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"<View />"})," component, and embed the canvas directly. I did this after investigating ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://sketchfab.com/3d-models/popular",children:"Sketchfab"}),"'s website, where I realized they solved the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"jitter"})," problem by not using ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"<View />"})," components at all, as they simply embed the canvas into whatever model-preview you're currently hovering over."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Although, that solution is quite traditional, it worked for my purposes however, so that's what I went with. Nevertheless, If you are creating a complete Three.js ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"experience"}),", then I'd suggest using Lenis. I say this despite my reservations, because Lenis or another virtual-scroller are really your only options."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.h2,{id:"my-favorite-react-state-management-solution-zustand",children:"My Favorite React State-Management Solution: Zustand"}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:(0,e.jsx)(n.img,{src:d,alt:"zustand\u2019s mascot, an adorable bear"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Created by the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://pmnd.rs/",children:"Poimandres dev collective"})," (Pmndrs)\u2014the same collective behind React Three Fiber & the React Three ecosystem\u2014",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://zustand-demo.pmnd.rs/",children:"Zustand"})," is a featherweight alternative to ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://react-redux.js.org/",children:"React Redux"}),", and I love the little state-management solution dearly."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)("aside",{children:(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"How could you not!? It\u2019s got a cute bear as a mascot!"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"It\u2019s incredibly minimal (feeling more like an extension of React\u2019s Context API), which makes learning it, and integrating it rather painless."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["In addition, because it comes from Poimandres, it integrates superbly into a ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"react-three/fiber"})," scene, with minimal performance impact. You can see it in action on their demo site, or you can see how I used it for my ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"toy"}),"-clicker game, ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"/projects/bot-clicker",children:"bot-clicker"}),", on its project page."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["However, integrating Zustand with React Three isn\u2019t the only way to use it, of course. The theme toggle in the navbar actually relies on it. While I\u2019m persisting the theme state via the localStorage API, rather than with Zustand\u2019s ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://docs.pmnd.rs/zustand/integrations/persisting-store-data",children:"Persist middleware"}),", it\u2019s kept in memory via a zustand store."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"To pass this state around, a provider component wraps the navbar & theme toggle, as well as any other component that needs this context. In effect, state can be sent from the sliding switch, to any of the wrapped components."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["While, the primary function of the sliding switch adds or removes the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"dark"})," class on the root HTML element\u2014this is ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://tailwindcss.com/docs/dark-mode",children:"used by tailwind CSS"})," to change colors from light to dark and vice-versa\u2014it\u2019s utility in being used in a Zustand store allows me to modify non-css elements too, like a Three.js scene to reflect the updated theme state."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Overall, I\u2019m thrilled by the existence of Zustand, especially having gotten used to the ease of ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://svelte.dev/docs/svelte-store",children:"Svelte\u2019s store API"}),", that makes state management a ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"breeze"}),". So, it was really nice to have found this minimalist, but really powerful, alternative for React as well."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.h2,{id:"discussion",children:"Discussion"}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.h3,{id:"overall-thoughts-on-nextjs",children:"Overall Thoughts on Next.js"}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Next.js 14 is the current major version of Next.js, having released close to a year ago (",(0,e.jsx)("time",{dateTime:"2023-10-26T02:00:00.000Z",children:"10/26/23"}),"), with the latest minor update (non-canary) just this past week (14.2.5). Now, having last used Next.js when it was at version 11?, developing with Next 14 has admittedly been quite the learning experience. Even so, I\u2019m overall quite satisfied with how everything turned out."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"Granted, the most common complaint you\u2019ll find about Next.js is usually in reference to the cognitive load it puts on developers\u2014a result of its breadth of features, customizability, and the level of control you have over its various APIs (caching, routing, rendering, etc.)\u2014and I don\u2019t disagree with that assessment. Next.js has a lot of moving parts, ergo it\u2019s a lot to learn. Additionally, it really didn\u2019t help that googling the various Next.js APIs and clicking on what pops up will typically take you to the old Pages router version instead of the newer App router alternative/equivalent API. The latter is a little better nowadays, but still not perfect (guess Vercel\u2019s SEO game was just too good)."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Furthermore, I\u2019ll even admit to knowing that I don\u2019t know everything about Next.js. For example, I\u2019ve got a rough idea of its caching model, but it\u2019s not as complete as I\u2019d like. However, this isn\u2019t because I think the caching model is overcomplicated, it\u2019s more so just been a lack of need to dive so deeply into it (",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"perhaps exploring it in-depth would make a good blog post?"}),")."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"Ignorance aside, once I managed to get a good enough mental-model of Next.js in my head, working with it was pretty smooth. At this point, I find most of the added thinking is spent in the optimization and testing departments."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["In sum, it\u2019s my opinion that Next\u2019s key strengths more than make up for its drawbacks. What I like the most about Next.js is just how, well, ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"next"})," it is. It integrates unreleased features from React (which, albeit annoying sometimes for compatibility, but I understand why), it\u2019s also incredibly forward-thinking in the features it provides, like ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"streaming"}),". Not to mention the level of control you have over even minute details like the precise runtime for a page route. Additionally, it\u2019s one of the most ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"batteries-included"})," frameworks I\u2019ve used as far as JavaScript/TypeScript frameworks go, and that\u2019s a huge plus too. Oh, and it makes TypeScript a first-class citizen to top it all off, which makes my brain happy."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.h3,{id:"overall-thoughts-on-ionsst",children:"Overall Thoughts on Ion/SST"}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"Ion might still be in beta, but once I was able to get things going, it's been a really solid deployment tool. Ion\u2019s major defining difference from its predecessors, and leading reason why I chose beta software over the stable SST v2, is that it uses Pulumi and Terraform providers to provision your IaC, instead of Amazon\u2019s CDK/CFN. The fact that your app\u2019s architecture can be made up from services provided by a whole host of different cloud service providers instead of just the services offered by AWS, was a major selling point to me."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["The only real drawback to Ion/SST that I can think of, is you\u2019ll ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://docs.sst.dev/going-to-production#deploy-from-git",children:"need to set up your own CI/CD pipeline"})," with something like ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://github.com/features/actions",children:"GitHub Actions"})," or ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://circleci.com/",children:"Circle CI"}),". Well, unless of course you want to run ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"sst deploy"})," manually after every commit, then don't let me stop you. If configuring that sounds like a drag, SST conveniently provides a CI/CD service called ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://seed.run/",children:"seed"}),", which should ",(0,e.jsx)(n.em,{children:"just work"})," with an Ion/SST codebase OOTB."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"Overall, I\u2019m incredibly pleased with using SST/Ion to deploy Next.js applications to AWS (CloudFront, Lambda, S3, etc.). Even though Ion isn\u2019t quite stable yet (it\u2019ll be renamed SST v3 by then), I\u2019m still quite satisfied with it. While it can\u2019t replace all the tools in my DevOps toolbox (nor should it), it\u2019s definitely going to get some heavy usage."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.h3,{id:"conclusion",children:"Conclusion"}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"This site is a Next.js 14 application, and with the help of Ion/SST + OpenNext, it gets deployed via serverless AWS Lambda functions, with integrated S3 buckets (& other AWS Services), where it\u2019s then distributed onto CloudFront\u2019s CDN for your enjoyment."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"While both Next.js and Ion/SST have their flaws, they\u2019re both fantastic tools in my full stack toolbox. Their strengths more than make up for their perceived weaknesses, and I'll happily use this combination again going forward."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"In addition, there's a whole slew of neat tools and technologies contained in this sites stack that I really enjoyed learning and building with. It's quite likely I'll find a use for these tools and libraries in later projects as well."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"Overall, I couldn't be happier with how this site came out, and I'm excited to see how both it and I, will evolve over time."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Finally, if you have any questions, or want to share your thoughts on this piece, or would like to submit corrections, please either reach out to me on social media, leave a comment below, open an ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://github.com/laniakita/website/issues/new/choose",children:"issue"}),", or submit a PR to the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://github.com/laniakita/website",children:"repo"})," directly. Whichever way, I\u2019d love to hear your thoughts, and I appreciate (constructive) feedback, thank you."]})]})}function m(t={}){let{wrapper:n}=t.components||{};return n?(0,e.jsx)(n,{...t,children:(0,e.jsx)(h,{...t})}):h(t)}return v(N);})();

featured_image.altText: Abstract art of a conical gradient. Next.js represented by darker colors on the left, Ion/SST represented by lighter colors on the right.
featured_image.caption: The totality is not, as it were, a mere heap, but the whole is something besides the parts; there is a cause. - Aristotle

html:
September update

Ion is now stable as SST v3! I've gone ahead and updated some stale parts of this article.

I've also since learned more about how Open Next works, and how SST deploys the bundle created by Open Next. You'll see strikethroughs around my old statements.

This article was a long time coming, it's also quite long. In some respects, this might feel like an article created from a few separate articles I stitched together, and perhaps it is. However, I felt it was important to talk about the primary technologies I used in developing/deploying this site, because they're all pretty tightly integrated.

To elaborate, Next.js is the application framework I went with, and I deployed it with Ion SST. The latter is important because it uses OpenNext as a serverless adapter, which takes the output from next build, and splits it up into bundles that can deploy on specific AWS Lambda functions. This effectively modifies how a production Next.js application is compiled runs to ensure compatibility with AWS Lambda / Lambda@edge. In other words, modifying how it runs, modifies the behavior of the production site itself (a bit). So, I really wanted to talk about it.

As for the WebGL stuff, admittedly, that section could've gone into a separate article. However, learning how to create with those specific technologies was such a significant motivator for myself in rebuilding this site, that it was worth including.

Abstract

This article catalogs some of my thoughts on:

  • Rebuilding this site
  • Developing with Next.js
  • Deploying with Ion/SST
  • Working with WebGL wrappers/libraries like Three.js & React Three Fiber (a Three.js renderer for React).

As well, I break down any last thoughts in the discussion section.

Introduction

Next.js is to React, like a glass slipper is to Cinderella; they fit perfectly together (usually). The same could be said of Vercelâs Cloud Platform and Next.js too, and yet, I used a tool called Ion to deploy this site on AWS instead. While I think Vercel is a fantastic choice for most use cases, especially for Next.js applications, something about Ion just caught my eye.

If you havenât heard of it, Ion is the upcoming v3 of SST, and itâs quite the Swiss Army knife of deployment tools. This is especially so with the switch from AWS CDK/CFN to Pulumi & Terraform providers to handle your Infrastructure as Code (IaC). In my use case, I used Ionâs Nextjs component which does a few very handy things in addition to some Next.js specific IaC which weâll get to later.

Now, the main reason for rebuilding my personal site was simply because it no longer reflected my current skill set. Unlike the site youâre reading this on, my old siteânothing fancy, just a Gatsby frontend on Amplifyâfrom a few years back was much less refined. So, I decided to wipe the slate clean, but I had some goals in mind. I wanted this website to be modern, yet ambitious, with an accompanying codebase that was flexible (read: organized) enough for me to feed my lust for cutting-edge technologies for years to come.

While the latter condition was solved by simply setting this site up in a monorepo (I used Turborepo for that), everything else meant becoming quite adventurous with this projectâs stack. I specifically chose technologies that would push me well beyond my comfort zone to both learn and to integrate. That ultimately meant leaving the ease and familiarity of Svelte and SvelteKit to build this site with tools Iâd once found overcomplicated and confusingâReact and Next.js.

Likewise, it also meant learning a subfield of programming that I was once wholly intimidated by, graphics. In effect, I used Three.js, React Three Fiber, and even some GLSL to add some fun WebGL-flare. This can be seen in the shader on the landing page, and also this mini-game that almost became such a page. I also happened to stumble upon Zustand, a lightweight state management system for React, which integrated with the latter very well.

But, I'll still walk through the below in that article too, since creating your own content backend is quite a project.

Likewise, I'm using it's integrated version of mdx-bundler, which is convenient in that it performs the esbuild step before next build. That means if I felt like it, these posts could be server rendered at the edge. That's pretty cool.

Furthermore, I even abandoned the various headless CMSes Iâve grown comfortable with over the years, in favor of something I can call my own. In effect, I wrote a prebuild script to assemble my data layer which takes advantage of Bunâs speedy File I/O API to find and process MDX files with gray-matterâand any contained featured images with plaiceholderâsaving the resultant array of objects into a SQLite-ish (libSQL) database on Turso via Drizzle ORM statements. I then fetch that data inside a server component to render it out in various ways, such as with mdx-bundler.

I also wrote a prebuild route handler for the blogâs web feed. That one It fetches the blog posts from contentlayer, and integrates them into a purpose built object which is turned into an XML string with jstoxml. While Iâd like to talk about this data layer portion further, it is, admittedly, a bit extensive. So, youâll have to wait to read about in a later blog post.

Beyond that, Iâm overall really happy with how everything turned out. While Next.js and Ion/SST arenât without their flawsâsomething not too unexpected of bleeding-edge toolsâthe pairing still came together quite nicely (in tandem with everything else) to create something Iâm quite proud of. Even if thereâs still bugs (read: mistakes) Iâd like to fix in the codebase, the end result works like it should for the most part. Page load times are quite fast. Its Lighthouse scores are decent enough (admittedly, Iâm sure thereâs still more I could do to improve accessibility). Thereâs still plenty of room for me to grow and build on top of it. As such, I donât regret developing this site with Next.js or shipping it with Ion/SST at all!

What I Like About Next.js

Next.js is a batteries-included full stack framework that does much more than just offer bleeding-edge features from Reactâs canary branch. Its expansive range of APIs and configuration options is simply unparalleled as far as full stack frameworks for React go.

What I like most about Next.js, is its offering of convenient metadata generation tools, and the deep level of control you have over its various rendering, routing, and caching strategies. Not to mention the customizations you can make to its new compiler+bundler, SWC, too.

With features like the above, is it really a huge wonder as to why Next.js might be the most popular full stack framework in existence?

App Router (& Server Components)

The App router and React Server Components are probably old news at this point for most React devs, but it was new to me. So, on the off chance youâre unfamiliar with it, lemme give you a quick recap.

The App router is more than just a refreshed Pages router that includes the ability to co-locate components with a corresponding page/directory. Itâs a major rewrite that enables functionality with React Server Components, an upcoming API in React 19 that has already caused a monumental shift in the React landscape. The very nature of server components even solves the majority of security risks involved with React based applications (see: How to Think About Security in Next.js). In short, server components are kind of a big deal.

Admittedly, Iâm still pretty enthusiastic about server components, even after all this time fussing with them in building this site. In fact, their addition was a bit of a factor in luring me back over to the React side of things in the first place.

While they do create some frustrating scenarios, such as working out how to delicately interleave client and server components, thereâs just something neat about them. Perhaps thereâs something to creating data heavy UI components server side, then shipping that to the client browser as pure markup, that just makes my brain happy.

Now, Iâd like to shift our focus back to the App router, away from all this gushing over server components, however, thatâs not exactly possible. One of the more prominent features enabled by this tight integration of server components with the App router is something called streaming.

Streaming is a pretty big benefit of server components, and I believe it can improve the user experience by quite a bit. The largest benefit to streaming, in my opinion, is summarized nicely in the Next.js docs:

Streaming is particularly beneficial when you want to prevent long data requests from blocking the page from rendering as it can reduce the Time To First Byte (TTFB) and First Contentful Paint (FCP). It also helps improve Time to Interactive (TTI), especially on slower devices.

I should mention however, that streaming isnât a configuration constant, or a special component like the App routerâs instant fallback loading UI feature. Streaming is instead, a server-side rendering pattern that can be implemented on SSR pages only.

When implemented properly, streaming results in progressively sending components over to the client browser from fastest to slowest fetch request payload. This is done by simply wrapping each component found on such an SSR page with a <Suspense /> boundary.

In effect, components that donât fetch any data will load first, while components that do, will stream-in to the client browser in the order it takes to complete their respective fetch requests. As such, streaming creates a better browsing experience as the page wonât feel stuck as it loads in. Well, given you can ship enough of the UI for it to feel that way, but I digress.

While these blog posts arenât SSR yetâergo no streamingâIâve prepared these post pages to do exactly that in using mdx-bundler. It relies on esbuild to render mdx strings live in production. As such, it really wonât be difficult to implement the streaming rendering pattern when I do. Especially since I already invested in the App router.

Overall, I'm quite satisfied in my decision to use the App router as my page routing model. Beyond the App routers integration of server components, itâs forward thinking-features like streaming that improve the user experience, gives me hope for the next-generation of web applications (is that why itâs called Next.js?), and that makes me very happy.

Metadata & Metadata Accessories

September update

In addition to the below, I've implemented next/og on an API endpoint / route handler to generate OpenGraph/Twitter images on demand. You'll notice these blog posts get the featured image if you share it, while blog posts without an image will resemble the images generated for a page like credits/bot-clicker. I'd originally intended to take advantage of the edge runtime for this, but the data I needed didn't seem to be making it into the generated Lambda@edge bundle. So, these generate dynamically from a standard Lambda running the standard node.js runtime instead. You can see how I'm doing this here: laniakita/website

This was quite a feat. It even led to me writing my own custom middleware.ts file. So, I'll try to write a blog post for this later.

With Meta having developed and maintained React, and React having not-so-subtly championed Next.js as the premier framework for React (at least for the bleeding edge branch), then, you might deduce that Next.js would be great at generating and working with metadata. But is that true? Yes, yes it is.

To demonstrate, thereâs quite a lot of metadata APIs included in Next.js by default. To give you an idea of how much, I put together the following list. It's an overview of the metadata APIs Iâm currently using for this site.

  • From the generateMetadata API
    • To generate meta tagSlugs on simple static pages, Iâm using the metadata Object.
    • To generate meta tagSlugs dynamically on dynamic routes Iâm using the namesake generateMetadata function.
  • From the Metadata files API
    • To auto-generate the various icon meta tagSlugs, Iâm using favicon, icon, apple-icon file conventions.
    • To generate the robots.txt, Iâm using a special robots.ts file.
    • To generate the sitemap.xml, Iâm using the generateSitemaps function from its namesake API.

The generateMetadata API is quite handy, especially itâs namesake function. Even if the static {metadata} object is somewhat tedious to fill out, itâs highly preferred over the tedious nature of adding (and updating) each little meta tag in JSX. Likewise, the namesake generateMetadata function that gets used on dynamic routes, saves both my fingers and myself an even larger amount of time given the dynamic nature of the metadata.

The generateMetadata function can even be paired with the generateStaticParams function API on SSG dynamic routes as well. Funnily enough, it even works similarly to the generateStaticParams function too. The main difference of course between it and the latter, is that the returned data to map over is plugged into a {metadata} object, instead of the {params} object.

Aside, the Metadata files API has quite a lot of time saving utilities too. Beyond the special files that allow you to generate things like the robots.txt or sitemap.xml with functions similar to those in the generateMetadata API, the file-based metadata generation for icons is a feature that I really love.

Like the generateMetadata API, it too has saved me quite a lot of the mind-numbingly tedious grunt work in hard-coding the different icons into their respective meta tagSlugs. The difference (and best part) of course, is that it does this automatically without even an object! All you need to do is simply give your icon a corresponding filename to its file format, in accordance with the icon file conventions under the Metadata files API, et voilÃ ! Essential icons automatically defined in your siteâs header!

While these APIs go more in depth, metadata utilities are one of the crazy-cool sleeper features that Next.js provides. Features that just seem to be absent in other frameworks. I suppose this might be because metadata & metadata tools donât seem all that important in the Proof-of-Concept stage. However, given the ubiquity of metadata and its uses, metatagSlugs can add A LOT of polish to the production build of a web application, in my opinion.

Regardless of how you feel about SEO, metadata shows up everywhere. The little tagSlugs are used in way more places than just search engine algorithms. In the web browser alone, favicon tagSlugs show a siteâs icon, title tagSlugs name the current tab, and minor tagSlugs like the author and a date show up in a browserâs reader view. Likewise, metadata and thus meta tagSlugs, are pretty much the sole determining factor in how a website will preview itself on social media.

For those reasons, Iâm quite pleased with the suite of metadata tools Next.js provides OOTB. Especially because tools like these set Next.js worlds apart from other frameworks. While itâs not so complicated to just write your own in-house versions of these tools, having these batteries make Next.js an attractive option for myself and I imagine other lazy time efficient devs as well.

Server Actions (Form Actions)

Admittedly, Iâve not had a chance to play with the Server Actions API too much aside from experiments with handling a userâs theme preference via cookies.

Note: Handling theme prefs via cookies

Speaking of, thereâs a really wonderful article by Mandaline that talks about how to do exactly that. I happened to stumble across it in this Next.js discussion thread that summarizes the approaches to implementing a theme toggle on the latest versions of Next.js.

My solution was ultimately more traditional (why yes, I did just apply suppressHydrationWarning on the root <HTML /> element. Thank you for noticing! >.<), but handling it via cookies is quite a neat approach too (I canât remember why I chose against it. Perhaps it had something to do with SSG?).

Aside, I should state my surprise to learn that native server side form handling didnât really exist in Next.js until relatively recently with React 19. I say that because SvelteKitâs had this feature for a long while now (see: form actions). Granted, Next.js has had the option of creating a custom API endpoint for forms submitted client side for a long while too (see: Next.js 14 announcement post that talks about this), which I suppose gives you the same functionality. Whatâs really changed is that React, and by extension Next.js, offers a native API to handle this, which simplifies the process; a much welcome addition.

Regardless, server actions now being stable in Next.js 14 are a much-needed feature in my opinion, and Iâm really grateful to have a Next.js equivalent to SvelteKitâs form actions. Likewise, I imagine that server actions likely make implementing an Authentication framework like Lucia a little less complicated, which is quite a nice side effect to boot.

Have Rendering Your Way

The level of control you have over how you want to render routes/pages is really impressive. If you felt like it, you could statically generate (SSG) one route, and dynamically render (SSR) pages for another route. You could even do SSR on the edge for that route (or another one) if you felt like it. To do that, you just need to export a constant in your page.tsx or layout.tsx:

export const runtime = âedgeâ // ânodejsâ (default) | âedgeâ

Now that I think about it, Next.js might be the only framework Iâve worked with that offers such a deep level of control over page rendering. I think the reason for this is that other frameworks (SvelteKit, Remix, Astro, etc.) have made SSR a first class (& sometimes only) citizen. Granted adapters exist for SvelteKit (adapter-static), but itâs sorta an all or nothing decision, isnât it?

Note: Astro

Apparently theyâve been doing Hybrid rendering since 2.0. While the level of control isnât as deep as Nextâs, itâs more than good enough. I'm appreciative.

Aside, I find this quite a nifty feature of Next.js that is also pretty much unparalleled in other frameworks. I really appreciate the fact that I can render posts like this statically, and if I added it, I could render a user dashboard dynamically on request on the edge runtime, served at the edge. I could do all of that without it being an all or nothing decision. Thatâs just awesome!

As such, Next.js is in a league of its own in the rendering department. The level of control it offers is unmatched. If youâve got a variety of content with different rendering needs, Next.js might just be the perfect framework for you.

What I Found Confusing Interesting in Next.js

I wonât lie, the App routerâs caching mechanisms are a bit complicated. You can learn more about how it works via this GitHub discussion thread in the main Next.js repo.

However, without reviewing it under a microscope, I donât feel it's possible for me to offer a nuanced opinion on it. I suppose I can point out that on SSG pages the React cache API has been quite a wonderful feature. I use it to memoize calls to my DB, so thatâs nice.

With that said, instead of griping about my ignorance, Iâll keep this section to something thatâs a little odd for a mainstream framework like Next.js, undocumented features. Such mysterious quirks arenât a bad thing per se, I imagine most softwareâs got a few, but Next.js likely has more than most.

Undoubtedly, these little mysteries are a result of Nextâs bleeding-edge nature, since features are often added faster than the docs can be written. However, this does lead to some interesting scenarios. The most intriguing involving the configuration of the Next.js middleware.

Middleware & minimalMode

In brief, the Next.js middleware performs its namesake function, as a control layer that sits between client browser and the server. Typically, youâd extend the middleware by integrating it with the NextResponse API to write logic that determines whether your site should produce a modified response based on an incoming requestâe.g., when to allow a request for CORS.

Beyond that, The middleware set to an undocumented configuration called minimalMode is the secret sauce which enables Next.js to deploy correctly onto Vercelâs serverless platform. The OpenNext FAQs discuss this secret middleware configuration further. They explain a bit about how Vercel builds a Next.js application, how the middleware gets separated out in the minimalMode configuration to be deployed at the edge, and how that process relies on Vercelâs own proprietary infra.

While most developers working with Next.js (and by extension Vercel) have no need to spare a thought to this undocumented configuration, I found it an intriguing feature of Next.js nonetheless. Admittedly, that might have something to do with how I decided to deploy this Next.js application, but I digress.

Debug Flags

Iâll admit, secret debug flags arenât as exciting as speculating on minimalMode and the mysteries surrounding Vercelâs proprietary infrastructure. However, this hidden flag may still come in handy during a late-night debugging session. So, letâs talk about it.

A while ago Iâd found this post by Martin Capodici on their blog that describes how they had uncovered an undocumented debug flag used to print out helpful diagnostics for the router cache in Next.js. All you need to do is set is NEXT_PRIVATE_DEBUG_CACHE=1, and the caching diagnostics are yours.

Like I said, itâs not the coolest secret flag in the world, but I did find something cool when I was reading up on it. Interestingly, I stumbled upon a rad little package called @neshca/cache-handler that just so happens to describe the behavior of NEXT_PRIVATE_DEBUG_CACHE in a little more detail via their troubleshooting guide.

Granted, I donât have a need for such a utility, but if youâre hosting a Next.js application on a distributed system like a k8s cluster, this might be the package for you. @neshca/cache-handler solves the cache validation issues borne from multiple instances of the same Next.js application, by letting you replace the default Next.js cache with a shared cache via special cache handlers. Cache Handlers for redis seem to be provided OOTB.

Fun caching tools aside, extra debugging information is always handy. So, itâs nice that Next.js has these flags built-in, even if theyâre frustratingly lacking in documentation.

What I Like about SST/Ion

The Ion flavor of SST is rad. I am enamored with its endless utility, Ion may as well be a Swiss Army Knife in my DevOps toolbox. In integrating the Pulumi engine into Ion, thereâs a wide range of Pulumi (& even Terraform) providers available OOTB in the form of components, letting you configure an applicationâs Infrastructure as Code (IaC) with ease.

Likewise, Ion provides a CLI in the form of sst, which does much more than just deploy your infra. Depending on your sst.config.ts, the sst CLI provides a wrapper around your applicationâs dev and build scripts to inject resources defined and linked in your IaC, right into your application. This occurs in both your local dev environment and of course on your production infra upon sst deploy; itâs quite wonderful.

IaC is Rad

Iâm a huge nerd, I get that, but something about declaring infra from a source controlled config file, and spinning it up from the command line just makes my brain happy. It probably scratches the same itch that Nix/NixOS does.

If I had to reason why Iâm so delighted by IaC, I imagine the reproducibility aspect is likely the largest contributing factor. Thereâs something inherently comforting about the fact that I can just copy my IaC files over to a new project (with fresh API keys). Equally, itâs nice I could even roll back my infra in the same project (based on the config from a previous commit), instantly creating the same backend infra as before.

While of course infra requirements differ between projects, itâs really nice to have a base configuration that I can use as a boilerplate in my other projects. If only because it saves me the step of rewriting many of the same infra declarations.

Likewise, the fact I can save even more time by skipping (imperative) setup hellâendlessly clicking through menus, double-checking everything looks good, then getting reset because I accidentally skipped a required fieldâis a literal godsend for me. So, the time savings factor (a direct benefit of IaC) gets a huge plus from me too.

Pulumi (& itâs Terraform Bridge)

The Ion flavor of SST uses Pulumi providers (& by extension Terraform providers) as components, that allow you to define your applications IaC. Whatâs nice is that you donât even need a Pulumi account for this, as the SST team integrated Pulumiâs engine right into Ionâs CLI.

Linked Resources

Itâs important to reiterate that Ion isnât simply a different flavor of Terraform, as SST themselves pointed out in that same blog post. While Ion gives you the provider components, it goes quite a many steps further. One such step is in allowing you to integrate your defined infra/resources directly into your application through a concept called linking.

All you need to do is link your defined resources back to your application in its sst.config.ts file. Once thatâs done, you can access them anywhere in your application! No other IaC tool to my knowledge does that, making Ion quite unique in that regard.

Open Next

The Nextjs component relies on OpenNext in compiling a Next.js application. Itâs an open source serverless adapter that makes deploying a Next.js application via serverless functions outside Vercel even possible with Ion/SST. OpenNext even attempts to achieve feature-parity with a Next.js app deployed on Vercelâs serverless platform, via an architecture based on a combination of AWS services and performing slight modifications to how the Next.js middleware is bundled and run.

In deploying to AWS, I found OpenNext to be a lovely adapter for my Next.js application. Everything just worked (mostly, we'll get into that). The best part was that I didnât need to make any tough decisions regarding runtimes either.

The latter is because Node.js is thankfully available in a Lambda function, unlike in a Cloudflare worker. While Workers offer partial support for Node.js APIs, due to their nature of being Edge functions, itâs unlikely Next.js will ever work 100% the same as it would on Vercel or even on AWS.

Runtimes aside, the only thing I got snagged on with OpenNext was the fact that sharp (needed for plaiceholder) isnât included in the final build.

September update

Sharp is always excised from the Open Next bundle. The best way to re-add it is to simply install it into server bundle before deploying it. There's two ways of doing it.

  • You can either install it into the bundle using npm install --arch=x64 --platform=linux --libc=glibc --prefix=".open-next/server-functions/default" sharp.
  • You can copy the version of sharp (& it's dependencies) you already have in your node_modules/ directory over into the server bundle cp -r ./node_modules/sharp ./open-next/server-functions/default/.

Since you'll need to do this on every compilation/deploy, you'll probably want to write a script to perform one of the methods above during the build process. You can see how I'm doing thing via the source code repo for this site (laniakita/website) for an example, or you can jump down to Transforms (Lambda Layers).

Despite the fact I included it as a dependency, plaiceholder just couldnât find sharp.

As a workaround, I used a Lambda Layer with sharp installed to it.

Then I just matched the sharp version on the layer, with the one in my package.json, using the SHARP_VERSION env. I injected that right before running open-next build.

Minor gripe aside, Iâm extremely grateful to the people whoâve created OpenNext, and all the wonderful people who continue to maintain it. While the little adapter might not give you the complete Vercel experience 100% of the time (how could it? Vercel uses their own proprietary infra) itâs pretty damn close, and thatâs incredible. Overall, Iâm quite satisfied using OpenNext, and I wonât hesitate to use it in deploying future Next.js projects.

SST Console

In honesty, I feel deploying things the hard way has meant forgoing some of the luxuries offered by managed serverless-deployment services like Vercel. Thatâs why itâs really wonderful the SST team found a way to offer the most important luxury of all, the console.

Granted, the SST console is a little slow (though thatâs probably more an AWS issue), it was incredibly helpful in debugging errors in production. Without it, Iâd be digging through the logs of the various Lambda Functions, trying to get a glimpse of what was causing my 500 internal server errors. So, Iâm very, very, thankful to the SST team for not only creating their own console, but offering it with a very generous free tier to boot.

Transforms (Lambda Layer)

September update

I'm no longer using Lamda layers to handle sharp. Currently I just run a script to copy it from my root node_modules/ into the bundle. This is primarily a workaround to the fact that I've not figured out how to just run npm install --arch=x64 --platform=linux --libc=glibc --prefix='.open-next/server-functions/default' sharp in my monorepo, without getting caught up in a registry timeout / 404 error for the local packages that don't exist in the npm registry. Likewise, bun doesn't support npm's --prefix flag.

So, I decided to just write a brute force script that copies sharp and it's dependencies into the output bundle from open-next, specifically into the default server function. A smarter script would grab the named deps that would result from a call to npm i sharp, then figure out which ones to install then copy over. However, Sharp seem's pretty stable, I was tired, and I just wanted something that worked immediately and I hard-coded the paths. So, have a gander at my silly little script.

/*
 * The bun shebang probably isn't necessary (no Bun specific APIs).
 * But, it ensures I get Bun's versions of the Node filesystem APIs.
 */
#! /usr/bin/env bun

import { cp, mkdir } from 'node:fs/promises';
import { join } from 'node:path';

const cwd = process.cwd();
const monoRepoCorrection = '../../';
const node_modules = join(cwd, monoRepoCorrection, './node_modules');
const openNextServerDefault = join(cwd, '.open-next/server-functions/default');

const sharpInstall = `sharp`;

const sharpDeps = ['color', 'detect-libc', 'semver'];
const colorDeps = ['color-convert', 'color-string'];
const colorStringDeps = ['color-name', 'simple-swizzle'];
// color-convert depends on color-name

const pkgsToCopy = [sharpInstall, ...sharpDeps, ...colorDeps, ...colorStringDeps];

const t0 = performance.now();

export default async function copySharp() {
  try {
    console.info('copying', sharpInstall, 'to:', openNextServerDefault);
    const pkgPaths = pkgsToCopy.map((pkg) => {
      const from = `${node_modules}/${pkg}`;
      const to = `${openNextServerDefault}/node_modules/${pkg}`;
      return {
        source: from,
        dest: to,
      };
    });
    for await (const pkg of pkgPaths) {
      console.info('creating dirs from', pkg.source, 'to:', pkg.dest);
      await mkdir(pkg.dest, { recursive: true });
    }
    for await (const copied of pkgPaths) {
      console.info('copying', copied.source, 'to:', copied.dest);
      await cp(copied.source, copied.dest, { recursive: true });
    }

    console.info('finished in ', performance.now() - t0, `ms`);
  } catch (err) {
    console.error(err);
  }
}

await copySharp();

I've set it up in my turbo.json so it runs immediately after SHARP_VERSION=0.33.5 bunx open-next build.

{
  "extends": ["//"],
  "tasks": {
    "build:open-next": {
      "env": ["OPEN_NEXT_VERSION", "NEXT_PUBLIC_DEPLOYED_URL"],
      "outputs": [
        ".open-next/**",
        "!.open-next/cache/**",
        "public/dist/**",
        "public/sw.js",
        ".contentlayer",
        ".contentlayermini"
      ],
      "inputs": ["$TURBO_DEFAULT$", ".env", ".env.local", ".env.development", ".env.production"]
    },
    "copy-sharp": {
      "inputs": ["$TURBO_DEFAULT$", ".env", ".env.local", ".env.development", ".env.production", ".open-next/**"],
      "outputs": [".open-next/server-functions/default/**"],
      "dependsOn": ["build:open-next"]
    }
  }
}

For whatever reasons, I just couldnât replicate the functionality of the old SST v2 transforms (a couple of months ago), to declaratively define and create a Lambda Layer from my sst.config.ts / project repo. What I could do is link an existing (imperatively created) Lambda layer, but I couldnât figure out how to create it from the config itself.

The reason I even looked into this in the first place, was because OpenNext doesnât include the sharp module in the production build. So, the only way to have those blurry placeholders you see generate dynamically, was by creating a Lambda Layer running Node.js with the sharp module loaded into it (thereâs more to this story, but that will be another article).

However, in trying to replicate this guide from the old docs, (whilst converting things as best I could to account for Pulumiâs aws-classic provider, inline with their docs), I found things would deploy, but I never received any sort of error message, nor did it create the Lambda Layer. This was very confusing to me.
